1380-1394., 189506=In 1376, the kings of France altered the royal coat of arms, replacing the field semée fleurs de lys with three fleurs de lys, alluding to the Trinity. This new design is referred to as France Moderne, the previous one being France Ancien. From about 1400 the kings of England imitated this change. As modified, the monarchs of England continued to bear arms in this form until the crown union with Scotland in 1603.[1], 164583=Married to: Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester; 1374-1397., 259555=Defeated and killed at the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485, fighting against Henry Tudor, later King Henry VII., 223242=Married to: Richard of Conisburgh, Earl of Cambridge; 1408-1411., 262334=Married to: King Richard III; 1472-1485., 250712=Executed in 1478 at the orders of King Edward IV (his own brother), for having designs on the throne., 230411=Married to: Richard of York, Duke of York; 1429-1460., 275478=Married to: John Beaufort, Duke of Somerset; 1439-1444., 209210=Killed at the Battle of Tewkesbury 1471., 69980=Married to: King Richard I; 1191-1199., 252497=Married to: George Plantagenet, Duke of Clarence; 1469-1476.}

textAfterTable: King Henry II 1133-1189 Gules, a lion rampant contourné Son of: Geoffrey of Anjou and Empress Matilda. In French blazoning, the lion rampant contourné was often termed a léopard. However, this usage was never widespread in England, and is long obsolete.[3] Queen Eleanor 1124?-1204 Gules, a lion passant guardant in pale Or[4] Daughter of: William X, Duke of Aquitaine, Duke of Aquitaine and Aenor de Châtellerault. Married to: King Henry II; 1152-1189. Arms Name Life Blazon Notes
